title: Retrospect AI: Autonomous Vehicle Trajectory Emulator
subtitle: Multi-Agent Simulation for AV Behavior Prediction
description: Built a trajectory emulation system that predicts and simulates autonomous vehicle behavior in complex traffic scenarios using deep learning and multi-agent simulation frameworks.

body.title: Motivation
paragraphs: Testing autonomous vehicles in real-world conditions is expensive, dangerous, and time-consuming, requiring millions of miles to validate safety in edge-case scenarios.
Existing simulation tools lack the fidelity to accurately model complex multi-agent interactions, human driver behaviors, and emergent traffic patterns that AVs encounter in deployment.

body.title: Technical Approach
paragraphs: Developed a trajectory prediction model using recurrent neural networks (LSTM/GRU) trained on real-world autonomous vehicle datasets to capture temporal dependencies in vehicle motion.
Implemented multi-agent simulation framework that models interactions between autonomous vehicles, human drivers, pedestrians, and cyclists with realistic behavior patterns.
Engineered scene understanding pipeline that processes map data, traffic signals, and agent states to provide contextual inputs for trajectory generation.
Built visualization and analysis tools to validate predicted trajectories against ground truth, measuring metrics like Average Displacement Error (ADE) and Final Displacement Error (FDE).

body.title: Results
paragraphs: Achieved accurate trajectory prediction across diverse driving scenarios including lane changes, merges, intersections, and roundabouts.
Enabled rapid testing of AV decision-making algorithms across thousands of simulated scenarios that would take months to collect in real-world driving.
System capable of generating realistic edge-case scenarios for stress-testing autonomous vehicle safety systems.
